message_1:
Find the diagonal matrix D and invertible matrix P such that $P^{-1}AP = D$, where A is given as: 

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 2 \\ 2 & 5 \end{bmatrix}.$$
 
Solve for D and P.
message_2:
To find the diagonal matrix D and invertible matrix P such that $P^{-1}AP = D$, we first need to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrix A.

The characteristic equation of A is given by:

$$\text{det}(A - \lambda I) = 0$$

where I is the identity matrix and λ is the eigenvalue. 

So, we have:

$$\text{det} \begin{bmatrix} 5-\lambda & 2 \\ 2 & 5-\lambda \end{bmatrix} = (5-\lambda)^2 - (2)(2) = \lambda^2 - 10\lambda + 21 = (\lambda - 3)(\lambda - 7) = 0$$

The eigenvalues are λ₁ = 3 and λ₂ = 7.

Now, we find the eigenvectors corresponding to each eigenvalue.

For λ₁ = 3:

$$(A - 3I)v_1 = 0$$

$$\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ 2 & 2 \end{bmatrix}v_1 = 0$$

We can choose v₁ = [1, -1] as an eigenvector.

For λ₂ = 7:

$$(A - 7I)v_2 = 0$$

$$\begin{bmatrix} -2 & 2 \\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix}v_2 = 0$$

We can choose v₂ = [1, 1] as an eigenvector.

Now, we can form the matrix P using the eigenvectors as columns:

$$P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

The inverse of P is given by:

$$P^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(P)} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{2} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

The diagonal matrix D is formed using the eigenvalues:

$$D = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 7 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, we have:

$$P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad P^{-1} = \frac{1}{2} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad D = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 7 \end{bmatrix}$$
